file_name: UNITEDNATIONALBANCORP_03_03_1999-EX-99-Outsourcing Agreement with the BISYS Group, Inc..txt

perturbation.original_text: As a result of its planned move to BISYS,  United  National will be  liquidating  its interest  in United  Financial  Services  during the first half of 1999 after it goes live with BISYS.
perturbation.changed_text: As a result of its planned move to BISYS,  United  National will be  liquidating  its interest  in United  Financial  Services no later than 90 days after it goes live with BISYS.
perturbation.explanation: This modification imposes a deadline of 'no later than 90 days' for the liquidation of United National's interest in United Financial Services. This could create legal inconsistencies. Liquidation processes, especially those involving financial institutions, are subject to regulatory oversight and may require specific timelines mandated by state or federal laws (e.g., securities regulations, banking laws). If the legally required timeline for such a liquidation is longer (or shorter under some circumstances) than 90 days, this clause would be in direct conflict with those regulations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State and federal laws governing financial institution liquidations (e.g., securities regulations, banking laws).

perturbation.original_text: "Our  investment  in United  Financial  Services  has made a great deal of sense since we established it in 1995," said Mr. Gregor.  "United Financial  Services has allowed  United  National to realize  significant  efficiencies  through the sharing of technology and processing  costs.  Nevertheless,  we believe that the enhanced  capabilities  which  BISYS  offers  are  better  matched to the future direction of our Bank."
perturbation.changed_text: "Our  investment  in United  Financial  Services  has made a great deal of sense since we established it in 1995," said Mr. Gregor.  "United Financial  Services has allowed  United  National to realize  significant  efficiencies  through the sharing of technology and processing  costs.  Nevertheless,  we believe that the enhanced  capabilities  which  BISYS  offers  are  better  matched to the future direction of our Bank. United National is not required to disclose the specifics or details of this evaluation to shareholders."
perturbation.explanation: This modification adds a clause stating 'United National is not required to disclose the specifics or details of this evaluation to shareholders.' This directly contradicts securities regulations that mandate transparency and disclosure of material information to shareholders, particularly concerning significant financial decisions and investments. Securities Exchange Act requires the public information and disclosure to the shareholders.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and related state securities laws.

perturbation.original_text: Bridgewater,  NJ -- February 18, 1999 -- United National Bancorp (Nasdaq:  UNBJ) announced today that its principal subsidiary, United National Bank, has entered into a  multi-year  agreement  with the BISYS  Group,  Inc.  whereby  BISYS will provide integrated  information  processing services, as well as item processing and deposit services, for United National.
perturbation.changed_text: Bridgewater,  NJ -- February 18, 1999 -- United National Bancorp (Nasdaq:  UNBJ) announced today that its principal subsidiary, United National Bank, has entered into a  multi-year  agreement  with the BISYS  Group,  Inc.  whereby  BISYS will provide integrated  information  processing services, as well as item processing and deposit services, for United National. This agreement will be automatically extended indefinitely after the initial term, unless United National provides a written notice of termination 15 days prior to contract end.
perturbation.explanation: Adding 'This agreement will be automatically extended indefinitely after the initial term, unless United National provides a written notice of termination 15 days prior to contract end' creates a potential legal contradiction. Many states have laws regarding automatic renewal clauses in contracts, particularly those involving services. Requiring only 15 days' notice to prevent automatic renewal might be deemed unconscionable or violate state-specific regulations requiring longer notice periods (e.g., 30 or 60 days) for automatic renewal clauses to be enforceable. Additionally, automatic renewals may not be enforceable if the contract does not meet certain disclosure requirements at the beginning of the agreement.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State laws governing automatic renewal clauses in service contracts (e.g., California Business and Professions Code Section 17600 et seq., New York General Obligations Law Section 5-903).
